image.altText: Trish cuts some wood using a tool, wearing ear muffs, a mask and high-vis.

props.synopsis: When Sunita Kotnala first came to Canberra, there was no women's shed, something she felt was needed. Now she helps other women gain the confidence to use power tools and make things with their hands.

title.children: Trish used to be 'petrified' of using power saws. Now she teaches woodworking

image.altText: A waitrees looks to the side as she holds a cup of coffee balanced on a saucer

props.synopsis: An expansion to the ACT's portable long service leave scheme, which allows those in casual or insecure work to access the entitlement even if they switch employers, is being put on hold amid the ongoing cost-of-living crisis.

title.children: 'Tough time' for businesses delays expansion of ACT leave scheme

image.altText: Ricky Stuart looks pensive with his hand on his chin

props.synopsis: Ricky Stuart says the NRL's crackdown on obstruction is over after Canberra was on the wrong end of a questionable bunker ruling.

title.children: Stuart furious with referee after Raiders defeat

image.altText: A man in a kayak holds onto a hot air balloon.

props.synopsis: During the Canberra Balloon Spectacular, pilot Justin Galbraith bounces the basket of his hot air balloon across the surface of Lake Burley Griffin and throws out a towline to pull along hundreds of kayakers and paddle-boarders in his wake.

title.children: Hot air balloons spending more time on the water as kayakers hitch a ride

image.altText: A backhoe clearing the hail from the road on the main street of town.

props.synopsis: It was already difficult to find a place to rent in Harden before a blast of extreme weather took a dozen homes off the market.

title.children: Renters with 'nowhere else to go' after storm smashes Riverina town

image.altText: A smartphone with an Airbnb logo on it in front of the same logo being projected on a screen.

props.synopsis: From July 1 short-term rental accommodation bookings of less than 28 days, made on booking services like Airbnb and Stayz, will pay a five per cent levy in the ACT.

title.children: Canberra short-term rental booking levy to 'level the playing field'

image.altText: A woman with short blonde hair holds up a moth-eaten knitted blanket.

props.synopsis: Releasing 10,000 of microscopic wasps into a home may not sound like the most obvious way to tackle a moth infestation, but it is an effective one.

title.children: These tiny wasps may help protect your clothes and pantry from moths

image.altText: A building with a sign 'Queanbeyan Courthouse'

props.synopsis: A NSW woman previously charged for hitting her 13-year-old son while chastising him for disobeying a technology ban has successfully appealed her conviction.

title.children: Woman who hit son during technology ban row wins conviction appeal

image.altText: A laughing clowns game in sideshow alley.

props.synopsis: The tradition of the annual show is under threat according to organisers who say volunteers are burnt out by the long hours and reams of paperwork it takes to run them.

title.children: Country shows at risk as volunteer organisers jump through 'endless hoops'

props.synopsis: Australians love an underdog and in 1983, Cliff Young transfixed the nation when he beat the world's best to shuffle to victory from Sydney to Melbourne. His legend endures.

title.children: Did Cliff Young accidentally cheat when he shuffled into Australian folklore?

image.altText: close up of hand holding money, five and twenty dollar notes and a one dollar coin next to a purse

props.synopsis: The release of the budget will inevitably involve a lot of political talk, but the government's plan will impact your financial situation in one way or another.

title.children: What to expect from tomorrow's federal budget speech and where to watch it

image.altText: F1 driver Oscar Piastri smiles as he hugs McLaren boss Zak Brown on the track at the Chinese Grand Prix.

props.synopsis: Australian Formula 1 driver Oscar Piastri converted his maiden grand prix pole position into victory, while three of his rivals were stunningly disqualified post-race.

title.children: Piastri wins in China as Hamilton, Leclerc and Gasly disqualified

image.altText: Pope Francis' first public appearance in five weeks

props.synopsis: Pope Francis made his first public appearance in more than five weeks, waving from a balcony at Rome's Gemelli hospital before he was discharge from the facility on Sunday.

title.children: Pope Francis waves from balcony as he's discharged from hospital

image.altText: Steve Witkoff standing in the Oval Office speaking.

props.synopsis: European nations have rushed to boost defence spending in recent weeks, who fear the US is seeking to turn its back on them to pursue a deal with Russia.

title.children: Putin doesn't want to take 'all of Europe', US envoy says

image.altText: Text message graphic.

props.synopsis: Hobart tenant Katie found out the "sublet agreement" she had signed with a company called Arx Pty Ltd could be invalid — and she had no tenancy rights in Tasmania.

title.children: Katie's sharehouse was run by a 'sublandlord' company. It could be unlawful

image.altText: Two women wrapped in blankets walk away from the camera down a freeway with cars gridlocked in both directions.

props.synopsis: Hundreds of women share their experiences for a new UN report revealing years of full-scale war in Ukraine has significantly intensified gender-based violence inside and outside the home.

title.children: The lights are off in Ukraine and women say it is fuelling violence

image.altText: Istanbul Mayor Imamoglu speaking with a microphone wearing a suit

props.synopsis: The decision to send Mr Imamoglu to jail comes after the main opposition party, European leaders and tens of thousands of protesters criticised the actions against him as politicised and undemocratic.

title.children: Türkiye jails Istanbul mayor before corruption trial amid protests in Türkiye

image.altText: Two people, their back to the camera, stand on the edge of a creek bank surrounded by bush. They are looking at each other.

props.synopsis: Australia has a painful past. For the first time, the country has been grappling with recording the stories of that history in a truth-telling commission.

title.children: Elizabeth owns the land where Russell's people were killed. They say it's time to talk

image.altText: Will McLachlan of the Brisbane Lions stands on the Gabba with his hands on his hips.

props.synopsis: The decision to start the AFL clash between the Lions and Eagles at midday in late March in Brisbane is questioned by coach Chris Fagan and club legend Jason Akermanis.

title.children: Lions set for recovery week after players left 'cooked' by midday game

image.altText: A woman with long brown hair sits on a wooden chair.

props.synopsis: The unbelievable story of adoptive parents abandoning their child — because they thought she was actually a grown woman pretending to be a child — is getting the Hollywood treatment.

title.children: Natalia Grace was nine when her parents made her become a 23-year-old

props.synopsis: Around the clock coverage of news events as they break at home and abroad.

title.children: ABC News Channel live

image.altText: Man on beach with four-wheel drive passing

props.synopsis: A global study finds there is "no environmentally safe level" of four-wheel drive use on beaches, prompting calls to severely limit access.

title.children: Calls for 4WD ban on the Australian beaches being 'pummelled to death'

image.altText: Mark Carney standing at a lectern and speaking, holding his hand up.

props.synopsis: The contest is expected to be dominated by Canada's increasingly tense relationship with US President Donald Trump, who has labelled the country America's "51st state".

title.children: Canadian prime minister calls snap election, days after being sworn in

image.altText: A middle aged man and woman standing in front of an ocean. The man is wearing is a blue t-shirt and the woman a dark blue polo

props.synopsis: Paramedics attending to Garry Tierney consulted a neurologist within minutes about his stroke via an app that aims to speed up assessments and tailor care.

title.children: 'Breakthrough' stroke treatment app to be rolled out nationally by 2027

image.altText: bushmaster-vehicles-upgrade

props.synopsis: The company that builds the protected mobility vehicles has unveiled a high-tech upgrade to combat the threat of armed drones, used with devastating effect in Ukraine.

title.children: Upgrade for Australia's Bushmasters to counter growing drone threat

image.altText: People putting sandbags together in preparation of an incoming storm.

props.synopsis: The Bureau of Meteorology forecast potential flooding on 14 rivers in northern NSW in the wake of ex-Cyclone Alfred. While only four actually did experience a major flood, data shows that several more were close, though all river heights were eclipsed by the catastrophic floods of early 2022.

title.children: NSW towns centimetres from major flooding due to Alfred, data shows

image.altText: A man standing at the side of a football oval

props.synopsis: Frank Golding is one of an estimated 500,000 former foster children and wards of the state, many of whom are now facing the worrying prospect of returning to managed care in their twilight years.

title.children: Former wards of the state face 'triggering' prospect of returning to care

image.altText: A close up shot of Angus Taylor standing in front of an Australian flag.

props.synopsis: Angus Taylor confirms the Coalition plans to reduce overall government spending growth and temporary migrant numbers, but says figures will be finalised after Tuesday's budget.

title.children: 'No ambiguity' on Coalition spending, migration cuts — but no specifics yet

image.altText: Fire truck and police officers out the front of a set of units.

props.synopsis: Police were called to a unit in Woodbine Street in Mayfield just before 11am on Sunday.

title.children: Man charged after six-hour siege at residential apartment block

image.altText: A woman in a tiara sits in the back of a car with a man in full military uniform

props.synopsis: At the age of 24, a brash and fiery Princess Anne was called "her royal rudeness" by the British tabloids. But when a man brandishing two guns tried to kidnap her outside Buckingham Palace, Anne's sharp tongue helped save her life.

title.children: How a fiery Princess Anne talked her way out of being kidnapped in 1974

image.altText: Writer Hanif Kureishi poses for a portrait in a stone and brick archway, wearing a black coat and checked scarf

props.synopsis: Hanif Kureishi does not pretend his new life is anything but often hellish and a profoundly unwelcome shock. But he has also been moved and sustained by new discoveries about connection, creativity and love.

title.children: 'I'm still capable of happiness': British author Hanif Kureishi reflects on life as a tetraplegic

image.altText: A man in a navy blue suit, white shirt and blue tie with short grey hair smiles at the camera

props.synopsis: Struggling to gain traction at home after taking the top job, UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer's performance on the international stage has been received differently.

title.children: Keir Starmer was struggling in the polls. Then he met Donald Trump

image.altText: Opposition Leader Peter Dutton

props.synopsis: Peter Dutton's misstep on the referendum is far from fatal but it comes alongside other hints the Coalition's campaign has stumbled in recent weeks.

title.children: Coalition loses momentum as 'thought bubbles' float into the policy void

image.altText: Matthew Dellavedova hands his NBL Finals MVP trophy to Illawarra Hawks Will Hickey.

props.synopsis: Melbourne United's Matthew Dellavedova is named MVP of the NBL Championship Series but hands it over to Will Hickey of the victorious Illawarra Hawks.

title.children: 'Class act': Delly gives NBL finals MVP to victorious Hawks opponent

image.altText: Sleeping woman

props.synopsis: The days are starting to get a little bit cooler, which means daylight saving time will soon be ending in the jurisdictions that observe it. But there are still two weeks until the clocks change.

title.children: There's still another fortnight of daylight saving time. Here's why
